nodeDataArray.text: Thinking Better on Purpose
What is Rationality?
Epistemic Rationality
Systematically improving the accuracy of your beliefs.
Building accurate maps of reality.
Example: Knowing where your laptop is in relation to the table.
Instrumental Rationality
Systematically achieving your values.
Choosing actions that lead to desired outcomes.
Steering reality - sending the future where you want it to go.
Why Use the Word 'Rationality'?
Allows discussion of general features of map-territory correspondence.
Enables generalizations about true models and better predictions.
Helps note general facts about thinking that produces truth or value.
Highlights systematic ways we fall short of rational standards.
Rationality and Psychology
Experimental psychologists uncover strange human reasoning.
Example: Judging 'Bill plays jazz' as less likely than 'Bill is an accountant who plays jazz'.
Gold standards for evaluating reasoning:
Probability theory: Laws underlying rational belief.
Decision theory: Laws underlying rational action.
Bayesian Formalisms
Beliefs conforming to coherent probability distribution.
Decisions maximizing probabilistic expectation of a coherent utility function.
Challenges and Limitations
Bayesian formalisms computationally intractable for most real-world problems.
Need to address human flaws, biases, and self-deception.
Questions about the meaning of math in certain situations (e.g., anthropic problems, Newcomblike problems).
Questions not fully answered by probability or decision theory (e.g., how to feel about the truth).
The Importance of Clarity and Focus
Don't get caught up in defining 'rationality' - focus on good thinking.
Use more specific language when disagreements about word meanings arise.
Strive for accuracy and achieving your values, not just using the word 'rationality'.
